concepts.definition: A design strategy that aligns each individual’s timeline to a shared anchor point within nested cohorts, ensuring that treatment and control comparisons use comparable follow-up starting points.
concepts.context_note: Used in TTE studies when multiple eligibility or treatment entry points exist, allowing each nested cohort to serve as a mini-trial with consistent time zero.
concepts.example: A study may create nested cohorts each month, aligning all eligible patients to that month’s time zero before comparing treatment initiators and non-initiators.

concepts.definition: A method that aligns individuals at the moment they newly initiate a treatment, ensuring all subjects begin follow-up at comparable stages of disease and care trajectories.
concepts.context_note: Used in TTE studies to avoid biases from including past users, ensuring clear temporal ordering between eligibility, treatment initiation, and outcomes.
concepts.example: Patients are aligned at their first prescription date for a medication, defining time zero as this initiation moment for both treated and comparator groups.

concepts.definition: A matching approach that aligns treated and untreated individuals on comparable amounts of prior person-time, ensuring they have similar follow-up histories and risk periods at time zero.
concepts.context_note: Used in TTE studies to control for differences in exposure opportunity time or disease progression before treatment assignment.
concepts.example: A treated patient with six months of prior observation is matched to an untreated patient who also has six months of prior observation before time zero.

concepts.definition: A method that aligns individuals according to the same calendar date or period, ensuring follow-up occurs within the same external temporal context such as season, policy changes, or epidemics.
concepts.context_note: Used in TTE studies when background risks vary over time, helping control for secular trends and time-varying confounders.
concepts.example: All individuals beginning follow-up on July 1, 2021 are aligned to that date so that both treated and untreated groups experience the same pandemic phase.
